title_sort: louisa van velsor whitman to walt whitman, 19 [february 1868]
title: Louisa Van Velsor Whitman to Walt Whitman, 19 [February 1868]
text: Feb 1868wensdayWednesday 19My dear Walteri thought i would just write a few lines and send you marysMary's letter it would be so long to wait till next week i didentdidn't hardly know how to spare the envelope i have been looking over my stock and i find i have got three more i suppose you have got my letter to day in answer to yours of sundaySunday last) i am feeling pretty well yesterday i didentdidn't feel very well but to day i feel as well as usual poor aunt fanny all her savings and money will not avail her anything we had a real snow storm here this morning but it is cleared off now i have not heard from George since he went away so i suppose he is well and wontwon't come now till the first of the monthwe had a visit yesterday from mr Brown of portland avePortland Ave. he was very clever looks about the same only better i think he has been out of work for a long time he says he has had some money from englandEngland that he had expected for a long time and it come very acceptable and willy and charlee works) i have had no more word from matty or hannyHannah or any body but this of marysMary's i dont know what i should doodo if it wasentwasn't for letters i read the trial in the stars paper i was glad Johnson was acquitted i think it was right i dontdon't seem to have much to write Walter dear this time but if you get any thing from englandEngland as you expected i want to see it if you get more than oneyour motherL W i hope you are well walter Louisa Van Velsor Whitman to Walt Whitman, 19 [February 1868]
